title: Kingston Flyer stalwart Russell Glendinning dies
text:
Kingston Flyer stalwart Russell Glendinning dies Last updated 10:50, February 21 2017 Grant Bryant 
Russell Glendinning stands near the Kingston Flyer 
A stalwart of the Kingston community and a train driver inextricably linked with the Kingston Flyer has died. 
Russell Glendinning, 80, died of cancer at Lakes District Hospital, in Queenstown, on Monday. 
He began his working life aged 14 as a railway toilet-scrubber and general dogsbody and by the age of 16 he was running the Balclutha railway depot. 
He worked in small towns throughout Otago and Southland, taking responsibility for the Kingston Flyer when it became a tourist attraction in 1971 and in 1975 he was awarded an MBE for services to tourism and railways. 
He is credited with bringing 39,000 passengers to the district in the 1990s. 
He also become involved in tours, films and commercials over 25 years. 
Glendinning retired in 2002 when it first moved into private ownership, intending to spend more time volunteering with St John. 
In 2005 he was made an Officer of the Most Venerable Order of St John. 
"My work for St John enriches my life. I work with some amazing and dedicated people," he said at the time. 
For many years he assisted in the operation of the Kingston Flyer under various owners but in 2015 he publicly severed his association citing owner David Bryce's refusal to accept the real value of the train Ad Feedback 
"The Flyer is deteriorating badly and its actual worth, plus any possible chance of it being repaired, has dropped dramatically. 
"It would be my sincere wish that the owner could display some respect for the value of the asset and its employment possibilities in Kingston, instead of selling off land and a carriage," he said. 
The train remains unsold.
